title: 'Fight Club' footage from inside riot-hit UK prison shows inmate being battered as crowd screams "finish him"
text:
Get daily   
This is the shocking moment an inmate knocks out a fellow lag during a Fight Club-style boxing match inside a British jail as spectators scream "finish him". 
The footage - apparently filmed at HMP Featherstone in Staffordshire - shows a crowd of around 20 convicts baying for blood as the fighters trade blows before the beaten man collapses helplessly to the ground. 
At least three mobile phones - banned in British prisons - were used to record the bout and not a single guard is seen during the five-minute clip. 
The inmates seem totally unconcerned about being filmed, making gun symbols to the camera and bragging about their links to criminal gangs. 
One says "keep the door locked" just before the fight begins and another replies: "Yo, ain't no-one coming in from now." The violent scenes are reminiscent of 1999 film Fight Club (Photo: DRN) Read More Prison football team pay penalty for bad behaviour after quitting league because players are always on lockdown 
The prison service described the incident as "completely unacceptable" and said the inmates involved would face disciplinary action. 
The footage - uploaded to Facebook last week - starts with a close-up of one fighter having his wrists strapped with tape. 
The camera then pans onto the crowd, with several inmates laughing, making gun gestures and saying "brap, brap, brap"to imitate gunshots. 
Some of the convicts seem wary about being heard by the guards and one says: "Shhh, yo be quiet, man." 
Another says: "Oi, keep the noise down so we can hear what's going on out there." 
One of the two fighters then walks up to the camera grinning with thumbs up and says he is from "Smethwick, A Ward". A number of savage blows are landed during the scrap (Photo: DRN) Read More 
The mobile is then passed around by inmates who take turns filming. One prisoner even films himself using the phone - despite risking an extra two years on his sentence. 
One says: "The wing's empty, you know." 
Other inmates can be heard saying "keep the door locked, man" and "gang members only". 
A prisoner steps then forward to quiet the rabble, saying: "All right then, let's sort it out. Anyone over-talking, we're battering ourselves." 
The prisoners back away and the fighters attack on the count of three. 
The first fighter immediately rocks his opponent with two savage punches. 
The opponent then lands one in return but is knocked backwards into the crowd by a flurry of blows to the head. 
The prisoners push him back into the fray, shouting: "Go on, and again. Come on." The full footage lasts five minutes (Photo: DRN) Read More Jails are 'full of drugs' says chief prisons inspector as he blasts 'failure of leadership' 
He is backed up against the wall and hit with another powerful combination, prompting calls of "grab him" and "woo-hoo" from the inmates. 
Pinning him into a corner, the first fighter eventually floors his rival with several right hands to the chin. 
The crowd swarms around as he rains punches down on the man, filming it on mobile phones and shouting: "Finish him. Finish him, blood. MMA, blood." 
The beaten fighter curls up and desperately tries to shield his face from the onslaught. 
It is eventually halted when one inmate says: "Stop, stop, stop, he ain't defending." 
The video was uploaded anonymously to Facebook last week but it is not clear when the footage was taken. 
HMP Featherstone is a Category C men's prison which houses more than 600 inmates. 
In August last year, a major incident was declared at the jail after inmates set fires and assaulted guards in a week-long outbreak of disorder. One fighter gives the camera the thumbs up before the bout begins (Photo: DRN) Read More Inmates post Trip Advisor-style reviews of 'holiday' prisons in sick insult to crime victims 
Riot staff were called in to deal with the violence - which included a hostage situation - and 20 more officers were hired in response. 
Speaking at the time, the Prison Officers Association said the jail had become "one of the most violent" in the UK and claimed there were up to four assaults a week on staff. 
In December last year, up to 500 rioters took control of HMP Birmingham after stealing keys from a guard . 
Inmates posed for selfies in stolen riot helmets and set fires, causing up to Â£3million worth of damage. 
Around 3,000 mobile phones were seized in just 12 weeks in UK jails last year. 
They are smuggled in by visitors, corrupt guards and even dropped over prison walls by drones. 
A prison service spokesman said: "This behaviour is completely unacceptable and we are working to remove the content from social media. 
"We are committed to making prisons places of safety and reform and are stepping up measures to tackle violence and find and block mobile phones in prisons." Like us on Facebook
